string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Question: How often have you used self-questioning techniques with your classes before?
Directions: Read the question below and choose your answer. Then press the forward arrow (>). Question: How important is it to have your students buy-in to your subject matter?

Directions: Read the question below and drag and drop the answer that best fits your opinion. Then press the forward arrow (>) to continue the lesson. Question: How do you feel now about using self-questioning techniques—that is, including directed self-questioning or promoting students’ self-questioning to improve metacognition and increase learning.

Question 1: Multiple Choice Directions: Read the question below and choose your answer. Then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. Question: Self-questioning is a learning tool that can be used to:

Question 2: True/False Directions: Read the question below and choose your answer. Then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. True or False: Only instructors can create the self-questions for the students.

Question 3: Multiple Response Directions: Read the question below and click on all correct answers. Then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. Question: Which of the following are considered CLOSED questions?

Question 4: Numeric Directions: Read the question below and enter the correct numeric value. Then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. Question: How many ways did we discuss logging/recording the student’s self-questions? Insert the number in the box below:

Question 5: Matching Drop Down Directions: Read the descriptions below and drop down the options and chose the best one. Then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. Question: Which logging/recording option would you use in the following situations:

search.slidetext: designing quality online courses by incorporating self-questioning techniques bobbi h.
introduction
welcome to the class welcome! today we will be discussing how to design quality online courses by incorporating self-questioning techniques
course navigation before we start, familiarize yourself with the articulate features so you can better navigate the course closed captioned
expectations this course includes many interactive opportunities, quizzes, a case study, and a graded final summative assessment at the end.
meet marci hello! i’m marci and i will be your guide. i may have a few friends join me, and i will introduce them as we go.
overview objective: recognize the benefits of using self questioning techniques in the online classroom

outline we will discuss the research supporting self-questioning, cover three types of questions a student can ask, and how the student can log these questions research (why) types of questions/question stems (what) literal inferential evaluative ways to log/record questions (how) journaling/blogging/vlogging adding to a collaborative document discussing with partner or team

assessment: slider question: how do you feel about self-questioning—that is, answering self-directed questions to improve metacognition and increase learning. directions: drag the slider tool to rate your opinion on self questioning. hate the idea, please don’t make me don’t mind either way this sounds fun, lets try it!
what is your opinion? hopefully you were all ‘thumbs up!’
triggering phase
big idea students process, clarify, and better understand the content of an online presentation through self questioning

i have used them in some of my classes i have used them in some of my classes i have used them in some of my classes i have used them in some of my classes i have used them in some of my classes i have used them in some of my classes i have never used self-questioning techniques i have never used self-questioning techniques i have never used self-questioning techniques i have never used self-questioning techniques i have never used self-questioning techniques i have never used self-questioning techniques question: how often have you used self-questioning techniques with your classes before? i’ve used them in all of my classes i’ve used them in all of my classes i’ve used them in all of my classes i’ve used them in all of my classes i’ve used them in all of my classes i’ve used them in all of my classes assessment: pick one directions: read the questions below and choose your answer. then press the check ( ) to see if you chose the correct answer.

debrief: pick one question: how often have you used self-questioning techniques with your classes before? a. i’ve used them in all of my classes b. i have used them in some of my classes c. i have never used self-questioning techniques ask yourself why….
the challenge online instruction can be difficult to follow/understand due to distractions or lack of interaction. we need students to think critically and stay connected.
new tool more activities, quizzes, and games may help, but the best option to promote ‘buy-in’ and improve critical thinking is using self-questioning techniques.

directions: read the question below and choose your answer. then press the checkmark. question: how important is it to have your students buy-in to your subject matter? 1 2 3 4 5 assessment likert scale strongly disagree disagree neutral agree strongly agree
debrief: likert scale question: how important is it to have your students buy-in to your subject matter? what did you think?why do you think that?
work smarter! the instructor is not the center of learning. using self-questioning techniques allows the student to ‘buy-in’ and take responsibility for their own learning.

metacognitive conversations add metacognitive questions to the beginning of class or homework assignments, and then ask students to report back to his/her partner on these questions. provide three questions you had about the assignment that you still cannot answer describe two ideas about this assignment that you found confusing did you learn a lot from this assignment? why or why not? how did you complete this assignment differently compared to a similar one before? what advice would you give yourself now if you had to start this assignment again?

neutral. maybe it will help, but maybe not no way. they can listen and take notes and do just fine directions: read the question below and drag and drop the answer that best fits your opinion. then press the checkmark to continue the lesson. question: how do you feel now about using self-questioning techniques—that is, including directed self-questioning or promoting students’ self-questioning to improve metacognition and increase learning. great! seems appropriate and makes sense assessment: drag and drop

debrief: drag and drop question: how do you feel now about using self-questioning techniques—that is, including directed self-questioning or promoting students’ self-questioning to improve metacognition and increase learning. directions: read the question below and drag and drop the answer that best fits your opinion. then press the checkmark to continue the lesson. great! seems appropriate and makes sense neutral. maybe it will help, but maybe not no way. they can listen and take notes and do just fine your options were: what are your thoughts on this?
self-questioning write in your journal some questions you may have: about self-questioning about instructor-led questions about critical thought about open and closed questions
exploration phase
questioning questioning plays a crucial role in learning, critical thought processes, and motivation. but are all questions created equal?
the purpose what is the purpose of questioning students?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment: pick many directions: click on the speech bubbles with “open” questions. question: can you spot the difference between an open and closed question?

debrief: pick many directions: click on the speech bubbles with “open” questions. question: can you spot the difference between an open and closed question? what is the coldest of the four seasons? what may influence your decision in choosing a major in college? what ideas did you have for your science project? what is your favorite flavor of icecream?
open/closed questions the students ask themselves can be open or closed. both types add value and increase learning potential.

three types there are three types of questions that are used in self-questioning. they are literal, inferential, and evaluative. literal: found in text/course video inferential: deeper thought needed, use context clues to look beyond evaluative: consider different perspectives, make a judgement, take a position

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment: drag and drop directions: using drag and drop, place the description into its question cloud. then press the forward arrow (>) to continue the lesson. question: can you match these definitions to their question type?

debrief: drag and drop question: can you match these definitions to their vocabulary words? directions: using drag and drop, match the description with its type of question. then press the forward arrow (>) to continue the lesson. literal evaluative inferential
recording questions it’s important for the students to log or record their questions. it is even better if it is in a location that fellow students can also access and benefit from them.

three ways the three main ways to log or record these self-questions are journal/blogging, a collaborative document, and pair/group discussion with a scribe journal or online blog google docs pair/group work
self-reflection utilizing these different recording techniques also allows the student to check back days or weeks later and self-reflect on his/her learning and monitor growth

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue assessment: pick one directions: read the text within the shapes and click on the logging/recording option that fits the question best. question: which type of logging/recording technique would be best for a classroom without technology that meets once a month.

debrief: pick one directions: read the text within the shapes and click on which logging option you prefer. question: which type of logging technique would be best for a classroom without technology that meets once a month.? using a collaborative online form like google docs blogging/vlogging discussing with group/classmate journaling
self-questioning think on the information we just learned and generate some questions: about recording questions about types of questions about anything else you are wondering about
integration phase

get ready let’s go over some guidance to make sure you are successful in completing the case study. you will be given directions and will be introduced to the characters of the case study there will be three activities for you to participate in although the case study is formulated as an opinion question, there is actually only one correct answer if you run into any technical issues, please send me an email—my address can be found on the syllabus

journal/blog a way of recording questions and discoveries as a hard- or soft- copy to focus on the subject, improve understanding, and keep a record of learning progress google docs an online collaborative document where a student can record their questions and another student can reply or add to the questions to enhance critical thought on the subject group/paired a way of discussing the questions raised by the students to get another point of view. it may bring about clarity, answers, or more questions. assessment: click to reveal directions: click on the tabs to see different ways a student can log or record their self-questions to enhance their learning and understanding button 1 button 1 button 1 button 1 button 2 button 2 button 2 button 2 button 3 button 3 button 3 button 3

case study you will be given an opportunity to assess a class and determine which logging/recording option will best suit them. directions: meet the class and learn their preferences. after assessing the class as a whole, make a determination on which type of logging/recording option marci should use for her class.

case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis finish case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis and lastly, there is alexander. alexander doesn’t like to socialize at all. he seems to understand the concept of self-questioning, but doesn’t want to participate with the class. finish case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis jonathon is very much a social butterfly. he does use self-questioning techniques and finds it has helped him with understanding the material. he does have a bit of an issue judging his classmates' questions when we use them for group discussion. case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis dennis is an expert with every online tool we use in the class. he seems to value the self-questioning techniques we have been learning and seems to be excelling in the course overall. case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis rachel has some troubles understanding using google docs—she has a steep learning curve having not much experience using online course formats or really any online tools at all. case study first, lets introduce the class: christania rachel alexander jonathon dennis christania has taken this class before. she seems to not want to participate with the self-questioning techniques that i’ve been coaching the class on the entire semester. she seems to only be learning our material at a surface level and doesn’t participate much in the online group discussions. case study first, lets introduce the class:(start by clicking on christania) christania

assessment: click to reveal marci christania rachel dennis jonathon alexander which would you prefer: blogs, journals, google docs, or group work group work please can we just journal? you know i’m up for anything! group work is probably best so i can help out! i like being part of a group so group work! journaling or blogging—but i don’t want to interact directions: click here to see which they prefer. assessment: click to reveal marci christania rachel dennis jonathon alexander which would you prefer: blogs, journals, google docs, or group work group work please can we just journal? you know i’m up for anything! group work is probably best so i can help out! i like being part of a group so group work! journaling or blogging—but i don’t want to interact directions: click here to see which they prefer.

assessment: drag and drop directions: determine which student would rather self question with a journal (green box) and which would rather use a group (orange box). group work please can we just journal? you know i’m up for anything! group work is probably best so i can help out! i like being part of a group so group work! journaling or blogging—but i don’t want to interact group journal

assessment: pick one directions: which technique would be best for marci’s class? click on the technique that will work best for the majority. discussing with group/classmate discussing with group/classmate discussing with group/classmate journaling journaling journaling
debrief: pick one directions: which technique would be best for marci’s class? click on the technique that will work best for the majority. were you correct?do you agree? why/why not?
case study debrief: what was your final decision?

self-questioning think on the information we just learned and generate some questions: what questions do you have about the case study? how would it play out if you had chose the other option? what questions might you need to ask to have more clarity about the case study?
resolution phase
add name directions: please type your name in the space below. this will allow it to populate onto your completion certificate. type in your name:
exam instructions instructions: this is your final summative assessment for this course. you must pass this quiz to pass the course.
exam expectations expectations: you must receive at least 80% on the quiz to pass the class. there are five questions, so you must get four of the five correct.
criteria for success criteria for success: complete the quiz with an 80% or better to receive your certificate and pass the class. if you do not receive 80%, you can retake the quiz.
technical challenges technical challenges: if you encounter any technical challenges, please send me an email and let me know of the problem.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct you are correct – all the above is the correct answer. self-questioning is a metacognitive tool that can cover many bases. it can help make sure the student understood the material taught in the lesson, it can get them thinking about the subject before the class starts by asking questions about it ahead of time, and it can make the student think critically promoting deeper thought. used appropriately, it can maximize the learning taking place in your online class. continue continue continue continue continue continue ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it ask yourself questions about the subject before you learn it promote critical thought promote critical thought promote critical thought promote critical thought promote critical thought promote critical thought all of the above all of the above all of the above all of the above all of the above all of the above question 1: multiple choice directions: read the question below and choose your answer. then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. question: self-questioning is a learning tool that can be used to: make sure you understood the material make sure you understood the material make sure you understood the material make sure you understood the material make sure you understood the material make sure you understood the material

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct this is false. self-questioning can be guided by the instructor, but it is a tool that is created by the student. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false question 2: true/false directions: read the question below and choose your answer. then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. true or false: only instructors can create the self-questions for the students.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct responses. continue continue continue continue continue continue do you like dogs or cats better? do you like dogs or cats better? do you like dogs or cats better? do you like dogs or cats better? do you like dogs or cats better? do you like dogs or cats better? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what time do you want to leave for the concert? what is your opinion of the new high school? what is your opinion of the new high school? what is your opinion of the new high school? what is your opinion of the new high school? what is your opinion of the new high school? what is your opinion of the new high school? do you think he will quit his job? do you think he will quit his job? do you think he will quit his job? do you think he will quit his job? do you think he will quit his job? do you think he will quit his job? question 3: multiple response directions: read the question below and click on all correct answers. then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. question: which of the following are considered closed questions?

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue question 4: numeric directions: read the question below and enter the correct numeric value. then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. question: how many ways did we discuss logging/recording the student’s self-questions? insert the number in the box below:

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct responses. continue continue continue continue continue continue a class with mostly new information google docs a class with much interaction pair/group work question 5: matching drop down directions: read the descriptions below and drop down the options and chose the best one. then press the forward arrow to continue the quiz. question: which logging/recording option would you use in the following situations: a large asynchronous online class journal/blog
next steps now that you have finished this course, you should take some time to practice these self-questioning techniques, then add to your course.
in summary this course provided a short tutorial on designing online classes with high levels of learning and metacognition by using self-questioning techniques.
thank you thank you for joining us in class today and learning how to improve your online courses by incorporating self-questioning techniques.

references aflalo, e. (2021). students generating questions as a way of learning. active learning in higher education, 22(1), 63–75. https://doi.org/10.1177/1469787418769120 in-text citation: (aflalo, 2018) contributors, f. of e. and uq. learn. team of, teaching, t. o. r. b. for i., & cambridge, u. of. (2017). ch. 9 questioning. granite.pressbooks.pub. https://granite.pressbooks.pub/teachingdiverselearners/chapter/questioning-2/ evewebb. (2023, may 12). how to develop independent learning skills. independent learning school. https://independentlearningschool.com/how-to-develop-independent-learning-skills/#:~:text=it%20can%20be%20achieved%20by king, a. (1989). effects of self-questioning training on college students’ comprehension of lectures. contemporary educational psychology, 14(4), 366–381. https://doi.org/10.1016/0361-476x(89)90022-2 loeb, s. (2020, march 21). how effective is online learning? what the research does and doesn’t tell us (opinion). education week. https://www.edweek.org/technology/opinion-how-effective-is-online-learning-what-the-research-does-and-doesn't-tell- us/2020/03#:~:text=some%20students%20do%20as%20well self-questioning - teach with tech | power up what works. (n.d.). powerupwhatworks.org. retrieved july 9, 2023, from https://powerupwhatworks.org/strategy-guide/self-questioning-teach-tech self-questioning: a guide for teachers and teacher aides. (n.d.). www.itac.edu.au. https://www.itac.edu.au/blog/teaching-strategies/self- questioning tathahira, tathahira. (2020). promoting students’ critical thinking through online learning in higher education: challenges and strategies. englisia: journal of language, education, and humanities. 8. 79. 10.22373/ej.v8i1.6636. teal. (2013). teal center fact sheet no. 12: deeper learning through questioning 2013 deeper learning through questioning. https://lincs.ed.gov/sites/default/ files/12_teal_deeper_learning_qs_complete_5_1_0.pdf

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Students generating questions as a way of learning.
Effects of self-questioning training on college students’ comprehension of lectures
How Effective Is Online Learning? What the Research Does and Doesn’t Tell Us
Self-Questioning - Teach with Tech | Power Up What Works
Self-questioning: a guide for teachers and teacher aides

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Unlike our previous questions, this one actually has right and wrong answers.Click on all of the speech bubbles that contain OPEN questions. Then click on the checkmark." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
